text.text: . ERB centers equity in the content of the toolkit and the process for using it.
Why does ERB content center equity and resilience?
- Disasters and climate change tend to hit certain populations and neighborhoods harder than others for reasons that often trace back to underlying social and environmental inequailities.
- Getting hit harder mean that they suffer cascading consequences (e.g., health and well-being, economic) and struggle more to recover.

- Resilience-building actions that also address equity are more likely to benefit those who need it most and have fewer negative outcomes for those already made vulnerable to disasters and climate change.
How does the ERB process center equity?
An equitable resilience process is inclusive and supports community empowerment. ERB guides you through how to:
- Establish a core team that is representative of local constituencies.
- Figure out who's working on resilience-related topics and expand your exisiting network.
- Hold community workshops to examine hazards, vulnerability, and resilience.
- Use storytelling to ensure local voices are heard.
- Collaboratively prioritize resilience and equity building actions that different groups will work on.
